user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_connection_reply:
```c
static void
check_connection_reply (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MHD_Response *const r = c->rp.response;  /**< a short alias */

  mhd_assert (c->rp.props.set);
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if ( (! c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers) &&
       (0 != r->total_size) )
  {
    MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
              _ ("This reply with response code %u cannot use reply body. "
                 "Non-empty response body is ignored and not used.\n"),
              (unsigned) (c->rp.responseCode));
  }
  if ( (! c->rp.props.use_reply_body_headers) &&
       (0 != (r->flags_auto & MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH)) )
  {
    MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
              _ ("This reply with response code %u cannot use reply body. "
                 "Application defined \"Content-Length\" header violates"
                 "HTTP specification.\n"),
              (unsigned) (c->rp.responseCode));
  }
#else
  (void) c; /* Mute compiler warning */
  (void) r; /* Mute compiler warning */
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
mhd_assert (c->rp.props.set);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The statement mhd_assert(c->rp.props.set); by itself is not unreachable and therefore does not violate Rule 2.1. It is a runtime check (typically a macro that tests the expression and aborts only on failure), so control can reach and execute it. A concrete violation scenario would exist only if mhd_assert were defined such that it unconditionally does not return (for example, it expands to an unconditional call to a non-returning function like abort() or a noreturn assertion handler regardless of the expression). In that case, any code following the call would be unreachable, which would violate Rule 2.1.
